environment_summaries.0:
California grows close to 100% of commercial almonds in the U.S. and 81% of almonds worldwide.
If you Google “are almonds environmentally friendly,” you’ll see results about why you “should ditch the almond milk,” “the dark side of almond use,” “are you nuts to keep eating almonds?” and other similar headlines.
But how much water do almonds actually use?
A single almond takes about 1.1 gallons of water to produce.
California dedicates about 8% of its total agricultural water supply to growing almonds.
Almond trees need water year-round, even when they’re not producing almonds.
And more almond trees are being planted in California, with the number of almond orchards doubling in the last 20 years.
The water almonds need became a topic of concern during the California drought from 2012 to 2016, the worst one on record since 1895.
The authors compared the nutrition content of 42 different California food crops.
They concluded that for the water needed to produce them, almonds ranked among the most valuable foods grown in California for their dietary and economic benefits.
In fact, almonds ranked at or near the top of all California crops in seven of the 11 nutrient categories.
And walnuts and pistachios ranked similar to almonds for their water use.
So, yes, California produces a lot of almonds.
But the state is a leading producer of another product that uses even more water… and that’s dairy.
So, if each almond takes about 1.1 gallons of water to grow, then it takes about 84 gallons of water to produce the almonds used in a typical store-bought gallon of almond milk.
By comparison, it can take up to 880 gallons of water to produce a gallon of dairy milk.
Plant-based milks not only typically need less water than dairy, but they also have a smaller carbon footprint.
Almonds are estimated to have a carbon footprint 10 times smaller than that of dairy milk.
And both dairy and beef cows use a huge amount of water.
Around one-third of the state’s entire water budget is used to produce meat and dairy.
Stunningly, California’s livestock industry uses more water than all the homes, businesses, and government in the state combined.
Alfalfa consumes the most water of any crop in California.
California, it turns out, exports more than 100 billion gallons of water per year in the form of alfalfa to countries like China, who use it for livestock feed.
In response to the recent drought, the state’s almond farmers have been working to improve their water efficiency.
And progress is being made: California almond farmers have reduced the amount of water it takes to grow one pound of almonds by 33% over 20 years.
And by 2025, the California almond community commits to reduce the amount of water to grow a pound of almonds by an additional 20%.
Nearly 80% of farmers across the state use efficient microirrigation systems, which conserve water by applying it where the crop needs it rather than to the entire field.
And the Almond Board is exploring if almond orchards can help replenish underground aquifers (which are used for drinking water and agriculture).
For these nuts to grow, bees must pollinate each blossom.
Almond orchards are the first natural food source of the year for many bees after winter hibernation.
According to the Almond Board of California, almond pollen is nutritious, providing all 10 of the essential amino acids bees need.
More than 70% of all commercial honey bee colonies in the United States are used to pollinate almond orchards.
And many of the bees in California are dying from pesticides used on almond groves.
Unfortunately, there are only a few million acres of almond groves that are currently certified organic in California.
As Ward Burroughs says in the video, “You cannot improve the health of this world if you’re gonna continue to put poisons and toxins on it to produce your food.” When purchasing almonds and almond milk, there are some good reasons to go organic if you can.
Certified organic almonds are grown without pesticides, which makes them more bee-friendly.
Homemade recipes call for a lot more almonds than store-bought varieties, so you can get more of their health benefits).
environment_summaries.1:
Also, 99% of the total production of almonds comes from California.
As California is in a current drought, and the fact that almonds require 10% of California’s total water supply each year, one could say that this statistic is astounding.
The effect of the amount of water required for almonds must be relatively compared, like all products.
This is exemplified by comparing the amount of water required to produce 1 gram of protein from almonds and beef.
For almonds, 1 gram of protein requires 4 gallons of water, while for 1 gram of beef; 27 gallons of water are needed.
As for water amount, it takes 6 times less the amount of water to produce protein out of almonds than it is from beef.
I have always looked at almonds as a healthier option, but I never realized how much water it takes to produce them.
From what you have highlighted, it seems that the extent to which California produces Almonds, proves unsustainable long term.
As soon as you compared it to how many loads of laundry you could do, I was really able to visualize how much water is actually being wasted to produce almond milk.
While it is shocking to see the statistics behind the water needed to grow a single almond, I still wonder whether people will be willing to change their habits.

Dr. Brodt showed how Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) was increasingly being used by the food industry and policy makers as a comprehensive tool for measuring environmental sustainability in food production by using several crops as case studies, including California almonds.
The study, published in The Journal of Industrial Ecology[i], is the most exhaustive food life cycle assessment study to date by the university’s researchers, and it demonstrates the complexity of agricultural systems and prospects for significant environmental benefits.
The Californian almond industry is being utilized as an important case study to highlight the potential for supply chain sustainability.”  “The food industry and policy makers can use Life Cycle Assessments as a comprehensive tool for measuring environmental sustainability in food production and this is an area that requires ongoing research as environmental conditions and regulations change.
This is a key area of focus as updating the LCA modelling research is already underway with greater emphasis on the co-products and surface and groundwater usage.” Current research from the California Almond Sustainability Program shows that 74 percent of almond growers use orchard prunings (tree wood, bark, clippings and other materials) for in-orchard chipping, composting, or energy generation.
[i] Elias Marvinney, Alissa Kendall, Sonja Brodt, Weiyuan Zhu. Life Cycle-based Assessment of Energy Use and Greenhouse Gas Emissions in Almond Production, Part II: Uncertainty Analysis Through Sensitivity Analysis and Scenario Testing.
(2015), Life Cycle–based Assessment of Energy Use and Greenhouse Gas Emissions in Almond Production, Part I: Analytical Framework and Baseline Results.

nutrition_summaries.2:
They are highly nutritious and rich in healthy fats, antioxidants, vitamins and minerals.
Antioxidants help protect against oxidative stress, which can damage molecules in your cells and contribute to inflammation, aging and diseases like cancer (4Trusted Source, 5Trusted Source).
A clinical trial in 60 male smokers found that about 3 ounces (84 grams) of almonds per day reduced oxidative stress biomarkers by 23–34% over a four-week period (9Trusted Source).
These findings support those of another study which found that eating almonds with main meals reduced some markers of oxidative damage (10Trusted Source).
Almonds are among the world’s best sources of vitamin E, with just 1 ounce providing 37% of the RDI (1).
Nuts are low in carbs but high in healthy fats, protein and fiber.
This indicates that high-magnesium foods such as almonds may help prevent metabolic syndrome and type 2 diabetes, both of which are major health problems.
We’ll send you our evidence-based tips on meal planning and nutrition The magnesium in almonds may additionally help lower blood pressure levels.
Studies show that correcting a magnesium deficiency can lead to major reductions in blood pressure (26Trusted Source, 27Trusted Source).
High levels of LDL lipoproteins in your blood — also known as “bad” cholesterol — is a well-known risk factor for heart disease.
A 16-week study in 65 people with prediabetes found that a diet providing 20% of calories from almonds lowered LDL cholesterol levels by an average of 12.4 mg/dL (28Trusted Source).
Another study found that eating 1.5 ounces (42 grams) of almonds per day lowered LDL cholesterol by 5.3 mg/dL while maintaining “good” HDL cholesterol.
Almonds do more than just lower LDL levels in your blood.
Almond skin is rich in polyphenol antioxidants, which prevent oxidation of cholesterol in test-tubes and animal studies (30Trusted Source, 31Trusted Source).
One human study showed that snacking on almonds for one month lowered oxidized LDL cholesterol levels by 14% (32Trusted Source).
Almonds are low in carbs and high in protein and fiber.
One four-week study in 137 participants showed that a daily 1.5-ounce (43-gram) serving of almonds significantly reduced hunger and the desire to eat (35Trusted Source).
Numerous other studies support the hunger-fighting effects of nuts (36Trusted Source).
Additionally, some evidence suggests that eating nuts can boost metabolism slightly (37Trusted Source).
In one study, a low-calorie diet with 3 ounces (84 grams) of almonds increased weight loss by 62% compared to a diet enriched with complex carbohydrates (38Trusted Source).
Another study in 100 overweight women found that those consuming almonds lost more weight than those on a nut-free diet.
Despite being high in fat, almonds are definitely a weight-loss-friendly food.
Almonds and other nuts are very high in calories.
Almonds contain lots of healthy fats, fiber, protein, magnesium and vitamin E.

Nuts are healthy, but high in fat and calories.
